DSS_METRIC_DESCRIPTIONS.METRIC_DESCRIPTION: Avoid local variables shadowing class fields
Both overriding or shadowing a class field (typically non-private) can strongly impact the readability, and therefore the maintainability, of a piece of code.

This rule will check whether local variables are shadowing class fields.
In case of C#, classes as well as structs are considered. In case of Visual Basic, modules also considered in addition to classes.
In case of classes, only non-private fields of Base classes are considered.
Ensure you have an explicit way, usually in form of naming conventions, to name your local variable to avoid conflict with class fields.
CERT, DCL01-C. - Do not reuse variable names in subscopes CERT, DCL51-J. - Do not shadow or obscure identifiers in subscopes

Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code - Bookmark to field that is being shadowed
Number of Methods
Number of violation occurrences
Child class fields should not shadow parent class fields
Having a variable with the same name in two unrelated classes is fine, but do the same thing within a class hierarchy and you'll get confusion at best, chaos at worst.
This QR will check whether child class fields shadow parent class fields. The check is irrespective of field type and case-sensitivity.
https://rules.sonarsource.com/csharp/RSPEC-2387
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of violation occurrences
Inherited member visibility should not be decreased
Changing an inherited member to private will not prevent access to the base class implementation
This rule raises an issue when a private method in an unsealed type has a signature that is identical to a public method declared in a base type.
https://rules.sonarsource.com/csharp/RSPEC-4015
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of violation occurrences
Track "FIXME" tags

FIXME tags are commonly used to mark places where a bug is suspected, but which the developer wants to deal with later.
Sometimes the developer will not have the time or will simply forget to get back to that tag.
This rule is meant to track those tags and to ensure that they do not go unnoticed.

This rule will check the use of FIXME tags in comment for method and classes. All comments, single line and multi-line, are considered that have "FIXME" (case insensitive) at the start of the comment.
Fix the issues in code and remove "FIXME" tags.
MITRE, CWE-546 - Suspicious Comment
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts
Number of violation occurrences
Track "TODO" tags

TODO tags are commonly used to mark places where some more code is required, but which the developer wants to implement later.
Sometimes the developer will not have the time or will simply forget to get back to that tag.
This rule is meant to track those tags and to ensure that they do not go unnoticed.
This rule will check the use of TODO tags in comment for method and classes. All comments, single line and multi-line, are considered that have "TODO" (case insensitive) at the start of the comment.
Complete remaining tasks and remove "TODO" tags.
MITRE, CWE-546 - Suspicious Comment
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts
Number of violation occurrences
Classes implementing "IEquatable<T>" should be sealed

When a class implements the IEquatable<T> interface, it enters a contract that, in effect, states "I know how to compare two instances of type T or any type derived from T for equality.". However if that class is derived, it is very unlikely that the base class will know how to make a meaningful comparison. Therefore that implicit contract is now broken.
Alternatively IEqualityComparer<T> provides a safer interface and is used by collections or Equals could be made virtual.
This rule raises an issue when a unsealed, public or protected class implements IEquatable<T> and the Equals is neither virtual nor abstract.
Make class sealed or use IEqualityComparer<T> instead.
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms132151(v=vs.110).aspx https://rules.sonarsource.com/csharp/RSPEC-4035
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Classes
Number of violation occurrences
Empty arrays and collections should be returned instead of null

Returning null instead of an actual array or collection forces callers of the method to explicitly test for nullity, making them more complex and less readable.
Moreover, in many cases, null is used as a synonym for empty.
This rule will verify that methods\properties that return arrays\collections do not return null.
Return empty array\collection.

CERT, MSC19-C. - For functions that return an array, prefer returning an empty array over a null value CERT, MET55-J. - Return an empty array or collection instead of a null value for methods that return an array or collection
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts
Number of violation occurrences
Interface instances should not be cast to concrete types

Needing to cast from an interface to a concrete type indicates that something is wrong with the abstraction in use, likely that something is missing from the interface. Instead of casting to a discrete type, the missing functionality should be added to the interface. Otherwise there is a risk of runtime exceptions.

This rule will check whether variable of interface type is converted into concrete type. Struct and Class are considered as Concrete type.
Note: Abstract classes are not considered as concrete classes.
Remove the cast.
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts
Number of violation occurrences
Ensure proper arguments to Events

With respect to guidelines from MSDN the following rules must be followed when raising events:
1. DO NOT pass null as the event data parameter when raising an event. 2. DO NOT pass null as the sender when raising a non-static event.
It prevents a null reference exception should a method try and do something with the arguments.
The rule will raise a violation in case of event raising when: 1. NULL is passed as sender when raising an non-static event 2. NULL is passed as event data when raising an event
You should pass EventArgs.Empty if you don’t want to pass any data to the event-handling method. Developers expect this parameter not to be null.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/design-guidelines/event?redirectedfrom=MSDN
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of methods
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using Assembly.LoadFrom, Assembly.LoadFile and Assembly.LoadWithPartialName

The trust level of an assembly that is loaded by using this method is the same as the trust level of the calling assembly. To load an assembly from a byte array with the trust level of the application domain, use the Load(Byte[], Byte[], SecurityContextSource) method.
This rule will check the use of Assembly.LoadFrom, Assembly.LoadFile and Assembly.LoadWithPartialName methods
Always use Assembly.Load as main method to load DLL.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.reflection.assembly.loadfrom?view=netcore-3.1 https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.reflection.assembly.loadfile?view=netcore-3.1 https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.reflection.assembly.loadwithpartialname?view=netcore-3.1
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of methods and fields and properties initialized using a lambda function
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid methods named without following synchronous/asynchronous convention

According to the Task-based Asynchronous Pattern (TAP), methods returning either a System.Threading.Tasks.Task or a System.Threading.Tasks.Task<TResult> are considered asynchronous. Such methods should use the Async suffix. Conversely methods which do not return such Tasks should not have an "Async" suffix.
This rule will check if synchronous task could be distinguished as Async or Sync based on name i.e. if async/sync suffixes are used in such methods as expected.
Ensure your methods name are following synchronous/asynchronous convention.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/asynchronous-programming-patterns/task-based-asynchronous-pattern-tap
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of methods
Number of violation occurrences
Culture Dependent String operations should specify culture

Calls without a culture may work fine in the system's "home" environment, but break in ways that are extremely difficult to diagnose for customers who use different encodings. Such bugs can be nearly, if not completely, impossible to reproduce when it's time to fix them.
This rule will raise violations if string.ToLower(), ToUpper, IndexOf, LastIndexOf, and Compare do not specify culture argument or CompareTo is called.
Use Culture argument or use culture invariant version. In case of CompareTo, CompareOrdinal, or Compare with culture.
https://wiki.sei.cmu.edu/confluence/display/java/STR02-J.+Specify+an+appropriate+locale+when+comparing+locale-dependent+data
var lowered = someString.ToLower(); //Noncompliant
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts
Mutable static fields of type System.Collections.Generic.ICollection<T> or System.Array should not be public static
If field is static and public and not read-only, it can affect every class that uses them. This can lead to unexpected behavior.
This rule checks for fields that are public static of type System.Array or System.Collections.Generic.ICollection<T> and are not read-only.

Make visibility of fields protected\private or make them of type Immutable\read-only. This can done through: - make fields read-only (with inline initialization) - is of type System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyCollection<T> System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyDictionary<TKey, TValue> System.Collections.Immutable.IImmutableArray<T> System.Collections.Immutable.IImmutableDictionary<TKey, TValue> System.Collections.Immutable.IImmutableList<T> System.Collections.Immutable.IImmutableSet<T> System.Collections.Immutable.IImmutableStack<T> System.Collections.Immutable.IImmutableQueue<T>
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts
Avoid creating exception without throwing them
Only creating exception and throwing it would mean that either it is a mistake or it is used for side effect of object creation.
This rule will check whether an exception type object is created but not thrown.
Throw the exception or remove the statement

var e = new Exception();
new Exception();
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts
Use Logical OR instead of Bitwise OR in boolean context
When Bitwise OR is used instead of Logical OR in boolean context, it is most probably a mistake or it is intended for side effect which is incorrect programming practice.
This rule will check whether bitwise OR (|) is used instead of Logical OR (||) in boolean context.
Use Logical OR
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts
Conditional structures should not have identical branches
Having identical statements in all branches would mean it is likely a mistake. Either it needs to be inspected and changed or conditional statement needs to be removed.
This QR will raise violation if all the branches in a given conditional statement has same content. switch with default label, if and ternary operators are considered for inspection.
Inspect conditional statement and change or remove conditional statement.
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts
Avoid empty finalisers

Whenever you can, avoid finalizers because of the additional performance overhead that's involved in tracking object lifetime. The garbage collector runs the finalizer before it collects the object. This means that at least two collections are required to collect the object. An empty finalizer incurs this added overhead without any benefit.

The rule will raise a violation when a type implements a finalizer that is empty. Even finalizer with only statement with calls to Debug.Fail and it is not in #if DEBUG part, it will be considered as violation since Debug.Fail is omitted for non-DEBUG configuration.
Avoid using empty finalizers

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/fundamentals/code-analysis/quality-rules/ca1821
https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/1069.html
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of finalizers
Avoid recursive type inheritance
Unlike methods, it is not possible to break out of recursion. If used, it will fail at runtime.
This rule will raise violation if Recursion is used in type inheritance.
Do not use recursive type inheritance.
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number pf classes
